posts.title: The Sounds of Black Music: Black Artists in the Heart of Country Music
posts.text: You may not associate people of African descent with country music, but the music genre that was once called “hillbilly music”—which evolved from European music and African influences—benefited from the cultural exchange of Blacks and whites in the American south.

posts.title: The Sounds of Black Music: There Are Many Kings, But Only One Prince
posts.text: June is Black Music Month and we begin our celebration with Prince whose boundary-pushing music provided the soundtrack to the lives of so many.

posts.title: Revisiting Malcolm X's Life and Legacy: Remote Resources for Readers of All Ages
posts.text: Whether you're looking to conduct research or learn more about his life and impact through a book or streamed discussion, the Library has a wealth of resources about Malcolm X.

posts.title: Bringing Periodicals From the African Diaspora To Your Fingertips
posts.text: Interested in locating periodicals from the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and don’t know where to begin or how to start your search?

posts.title: Remembering Playwrights William Branch and Mustapha Matura
posts.text: Both were prolific dramatists who used their craft to portray the contours, complexity and tensions of the lives of people in the African diaspora.

posts.title: Black Solidarity Day Turns 50
posts.text: The recent, 50th anniversary of Black Solidarity Day on November 4 provides an opportunity to reflect on the day's origins using resources available at the New York Public Library and, specifically, at the Schomburg Center for Research and Black Culture.

posts.title: BaddDDD Sonia Sanchez: Celebrating the Work of an Iconic Wordsmith and Activist
posts.text: We look at the contributions of this award-winning African American poet, activist, educator, and mentor, who's also an ambassador for the NYPL Schomburg Society.

posts.title: Black Theater Artists In Their Formative Years: Crossing Paths At The Frank Silvera Writers' Workshop
posts.text: During the Black Theatre Movement of the 1960s and 1970s, New York City saw an emergence of theater companies led by artists of African descent. One influential group became the laboratory for hundreds of playwrights and the launching pad for some of America's most notable actors.

posts.title: Introducing the African American Theater Research Guide
posts.text: For the first time in a generation, the current theater season in New York City is offering a smorgasbord of productions by theater artists from the African diaspora. The African American Theater Research Guide is intended to be a resource for those interested in digging into an illuminating trove of materials at the Schomburg Center, by and about African American theater makers.

posts.title: Black Feminism Introductory Research Guide
posts.text: The Schomburg Center's new guide serves as an excellent starting point for anyone studying or researching Black feminism and features notable figures from the Black feminist movement including Alice Walker, Audre Lorde, and others.

posts.title: Introducing The Black Bookstore Research Guide
posts.text: The history and rich tradition of Black-owned bookstores in the United States are now highlighted in a new research guide, dating back to the first Black-owned bookstore in 1834.

posts.title: Alvenia Fulton: A Pioneer in the Health and Wellness Industry
posts.text: She was once called "The Dietitian to the Stars." Read about this African American trailblazer in the fields of nutrition and health.

posts.title: Our Eyes Are On Zora Neale Hurston
posts.text: This past fall marked the 80th anniversary of the publication of Zora Neale Hurston’s iconic novel Their Eyes Were Watching God. In honor of the novel, a display titled Our Eyes Are On Zora is on display in the Schomburg Center For Research in Black Culture.

posts.title: "Get Out" Reading and Viewing List
posts.text: As Get Out was recently released, what better time than now to unpack the many layers and images in the film with NYPL’s resources: some of which are available at the Schomburg Center for Research in Black Culture and others may be found at NYPL’s research and branch libraries.

posts.title: Celebrating African Americans in Fashion
posts.text: On February 27, 2017, Model Behavior, a program featuring a talk between, Pat Cleveland and Coco Mitchell, two legendary African American models, was held at the Schomburg Center. The conversation, moderated by author and fashion industry expert Constance C.R. White, was held in conjunction with FIT’s exhibit Black Fashion Designers that runs through May 16, 2017.

posts.title: Farewell to Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor and Gloria Naylor
posts.text: This past fall, the world lost two influential African American women writers: Vertamae Smart-Grosvenor and Gloria Naylor.

posts.title: Evaluating the Struggle for Equality and Civil Rights in the U.S. with the NAACP Papers
posts.text: The NAACP Papers—an archival collection of approximately two million historical documents from NAACP national, legal and branch offices—are now available online to researchers onsite at the Schomburg Center, and NYPL's other research and branch libraries, as well as remotely.

posts.title: Keeping #TonysSoDiverse Beyond the 2015-2016 Season
posts.text: It is too soon to tell if the next Broadway season will boast the same number of projects that star Asian-Americans, Latinos, African-Americans, deaf and disabled artists that it did this year, but it looks promising. Here’s a look at upcoming projects that are scheduled to open soon.

posts.title: Countee Cullen Remembered With Exhibits and Celebration
posts.text: Celebrate Countee Cullen’s birthday on Tuesday, May 31 at the Countee Cullen Library and the Jean Blackwell Hutson Research and Reference Division of the Schomburg Center.

posts.title: Playwright Pays Homage To Legendary MCs With Play Cycle
posts.text: Shaun Neblett, aka MC SNEB, is a playwright, educator, and founder of Changing Perceptions Theater.

posts.title: African Americans on Broadway Then and Now
posts.text: The 2015-2016 Broadway theater season is being hailed as one of the most diverse on record. Is this slate of shows featuring African Americans on Broadway unprecedented?  Let’s look take a look back into American theater history to approximately 70 years ago.
